name: sodium borate mine operation and beneficiation | sodium borates | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/27057/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of sodium borate from borax, a naturally occurring mineral containing boron in form of B2O3. After being extracted from open pit sites and crushed, the ores are ;dissolved in water and screened to separate the resulting insolubles from the solution. Sodium borate is especially used in household products, such as detergents and disinfectant. This dataset considers the production of sodium borate occurring in open pit sites in the US, which together with Turkey are the world’s leading producers of boron minerals (USGS, 2017. Minerals Yearbook - Boron). ;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - sodium borates production, US, 2000 - 2000 (578f9a46-e616-4501-b42a-c01c5d1d453e)]

The activity starts with the mining of borax (Na2B4O7*10H2O) from the ground. 

The activity ends with the production of sodium borate (anhydrous).
category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/089:Mining and quarrying n.e.c./0891:Mining of chemical and fertilizer minerals
tags: Sector: Resource Extraction; Minerals; Agriculture & Animal Husbandry

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data used are assumed to represent conditions in the US. Proxy data from a study in Mexico were used for some flows. See specific comments to exchanges.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Sodium borates are obtained from surface mining of borax (Na2B4O7 * 10H2O) deposits, also called tincal. Open pit mining requires drilling and blasting to reach load deposits. Ores are removed from the mine and transported to milling and beneficiating plants for concentrating the ore. After being crushed, the ores are ;dissolved in water and screened to separate the resulting insolubles from the solution. The crystals of sodium borate are dried from the solution and can either be sold as anhydrous borax or treated further to produce other borate materials.;References: ;US EPA. Archive document - Boron. Available at: https://archive.epa.gov/pesticides/reregistration/web/pdf/0024fact.pdf;US Borax, 2019. Boron operations brochure. Available at: https://www.borax.com/BoraxCorp/media/Borax-Main/Resources/Brochures/boron-operations.pdf
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
The amount of boron in ground is extrapolated from the information available for borax deposits in Turkey (Acarkan et al., 2005), and the inputs of energy, diesel and process water were approximated from the pre-feasibility study in Mexican colemanite deposits (Allard et al., 2013). The amount of airborne emissions was retrieved from the Energy and Environmental Profile of the U.S. Mining Industry (2013). The amount of gangue in ground, the tailings and wastewater were calculated to obtain mass balance, For further details, see comments to the related exchanges. 

References:
Acarkan, N., Bulut, G., Kangal, O., & Önal, G. (2005). A new process for upgrading boron content and recovery of borax concentrate. Minerals Engineering, 18(7), 739-741
Allard, G., Salazar Velazquez, R., Verley, C.G., Vidal, M.F., 2013. Preliminary Economic Assessment for the El Cajon Borate Deposit, Magdalena Basin Project, Sonora, Mexico (Pursuant to National Instrument 43-101 of the Canadian Securities Administrators)
Energy and Environmental Profile of the U.S. Mining Industry, 2013. Chapter 3: Potash, Soda Ash, and Borates. Table 3-6, Available at:  https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/11/f4/potash_soda_borate.pdf
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Due to lack of specific information on the extraction of boron from natural borax in the US, some values were approximated and others copied from the previous dataset "sodium borate production" (GLO) as published in ecoinvent v.3.8, based on Althaus et al. (2007). See Extrapolations and exchange comments for more details.

Reference:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, from www.ecoinvent.org <http://www.ecoinvent.org>.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value, based on B2O3 content in both borax ores (26-27%) and in sodium borate (32-33%). The recovery rate of B2O3 is 78.7%.

Reference: 
Acarkan, N., Bulut, G., Kangal, O., & Önal, G. (2005). A new process for upgrading boron content and recovery of borax concentrate. Minerals Engineering, 18(7), 739-741.

Approximation from the pre-feasibility study of colemanite deposits in Mexico (Chapter  21.0 Capital and operating coast, Table 22): 50m3 natural gas are required for 1 metric ton colemanite. 36.3 MJ/m3 --> Conversion in MJ in data quality guidelines.

Reference:
Allard, G., Salazar Velazquez, R., Verley, C.G., Vidal, M.F., 2013. Preliminary Economic Assessment for the El Cajon Borate Deposit, Magdalena Basin Project, Sonora, Mexico (Pursuant to National Instrument 43-101 of the Canadian Securities Administrators).

exchanges.description:
Amount taken from the dataset "sodium borates production" (GLO) as published in ecoinvent v3.8, based on Althaus et al. (2007). 

Reference:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, from www.ecoinvent.org <http://www.ecoinvent.org>.

Calculated value based on boron content in natural borax in ground. Approximation from borax deposits in Turckey. Acarkan et al. (2005) report that borax ore of 26-27% B2O3 is treated to produce a concentrate having 32-33% B2O3. Recovery rate is 78.7%. B MW = 10.81 g/mol; O MW = 16 g/mol

Reference: 
Acarkan, N., Bulut, G., Kangal, O., & Önal, G. (2005). A new process for upgrading boron content and recovery of borax concentrate. Minerals Engineering, 18(7), 739-741.

EcoSpold01Location=GLO
Approximation from the pre-feasibility study of colemanite deposits in Mexico (Chapter  21.0 Capital and operating coast, Table 22): 143 tonnes of fuel are required for 50K tonnes of colemanite.  Conversion in MJ: 42.8 MJ/kg according to Ecoinvent data quality guidelines. 

Reference:
Allard, G., Salazar Velazquez, R., Verley, C.G., Vidal, M.F., 2013. Preliminary Economic Assessment for the El Cajon Borate Deposit, Magdalena Basin Project, Sonora, Mexico (Pursuant to National Instrument 43-101 of the Canadian Securities Administrators). 
Weidema et al. 2013.  Overview and methodology - Data quality guideline for the ecoinvent database version 3.
